title: Using Art Movements to Inspire Photography
summary: Lindsay Adler introduces a tutorial on leveraging art history movements—specifically Impressionism, Cubism, Color Field Painting, and Nouveau Réalisme—to create six distinct photography concepts using creative in-camera effects and styling.

steps.action: Introduction to using art movements and styles as inspiration for photography concepts.
Explore Impressionism by shooting through textured materials to create a painterly look.
Explore Cubism using geometric set designs and angular styling.
Explore Color Field Painting using bold body paint and matching backgrounds.
Explore Nouveau Réalisme with monochromatic blue styling.
Utilize in-camera creative effects to mimic aesthetic qualities like brushstrokes.
Edit photos to enhance the abstract and painterly results.

key_takeaways: Art movements can provide a framework for creative direction in photography.
In-camera effects, such as shooting through textured objects, can simulate brushstrokes and abstract aesthetics.
Combining set design, styling, and lighting allows photographers to pay homage to specific artists or styles.
